data.title: Countries, nationalities, & languages in Spanish: A big guide
data.meta_description: Ready to become a child of the world by learning all about countries, cities, nationalities, & languages in Spanish? Pack your bags - letâs go!
data.text:
Learning Spanish and traveling abroad can instantly turn you into an ambassador of your home country.

As you follow the wonderfully-exciting roads that learning Spanish can take you, youâre bound to find yourself in one of the many Spanish-speaking countries. When you do, youâll without a doubt end up meeting tons of people, saying hi, introducing yourself, and ultimately answering the question: "where are you from?â in Spanish.

Knowing how to talk about countries, cities, and nationalities will help you make more friends, cultivate more genuine connections, and learn more about the places you visit. Even when you meet locals, donât always assume that theyâre also from there. Many may be from neighboring towns, or even far away places, so talking with them about where theyâre from will help you better understand the people, culture, and geography of the country youâre in.

Plus, if youâre interested in an international career, youâll need some of this vocabulary just to get by. Not only will you need to talk about other countries (including non-Spanish speaking ones!), but youâll also likely need to know the names of political organizations such as the UN, the European Union, and more. But fret not; weâve included all of those in this handy article!

Ready to become a child of the world by learning all about countries, cities, nationalities, and languages in Spanish? Pack your bags and letâs go!

List of countries in Spanish

According to the United Nations definitions, there are currently 195 countries in the world. Weâve included over half of them in our list below so you can learn how to say your country in Spanish. Watch out, though, as many countries have only slight differences between English and Spanish. For example, Brazil in Spanish is spelled with an s (Brasil) and Canada has an accent mark at the end (CanadÃ¡).

Weâve broken down the list of countries in Spanish by continent to make it even easier to find your native country. By the way, the total number of continents varies depending on whom you ask. Most people in Latin America learn that there are only five continents, which is why weâve split our list into just five!

African countries in Spanish

List of cities in Spanish

If youâd like to get more specific, you can also say which city youâre from. Weâve compiled a list of the largest cities in the world in Spanish so you can be as specific as you want when mentioning where youâre from.

Since a large proportion of our readers is from the US, weâve also included a separate table with some of the largest cities in the US. You can find it immediately after the table below.

List of cities in the United States

Here are some of the largest cities in the United States. Remember that many of these were named when they were part of Mexico or the Spanish Empire, so their names are already in Spanish!

You should also note that most people around the world wonât be very familiar with cities in the US. Of course, almost everybody will know New York City, but you probably shouldnât just say âAustinâ and expect Spanish speakers to know where that is. Instead, specify that youâre from a city in the US called Austin.

Washington D. C. waËsiÌnÉ¡toÌn wash-eeng-ton Boston Boston ËbostoÌn bos-ton

Nationalities in Spanish

Finally, you should know some nationalities in Spanish to easily describe where youâre from and also where your friends and colleagues are from. Note that nationalities in Spanish do not need to be capitalized!

One thing that may irk a lot of Latin Americans is when people from the US use the term âAmericanâ to refer to themselves. As you may have noticed from the section on countries above, Latin Americans consider both North America and South America to be the same continent: America. Thus, in Spanish, someone from Uruguay is just as American as someone from the United States, in the sense that they are both from the American continent.

So, if youâre from the US, make sure to only use estadounidense to refer to your nationality. You may also hear other terms like âgringoâ or âyankee,â which can be neutral or derogatory depending on the context. You may also use âgringoâ to refer to yourself if you want to be a little tongue-in-cheek.

Languages in Spanish

Another bit of information that youâll likely want to share after saying where youâre from is what language you speak at home. Luckily, many languages have the same name as the nationality of the countries they are from, just like in English.

You should still take a moment to look at the table of languages in Spanish below, as some are not the same. For example, someone from Finland is a finlandÃ©s, but the language spoken in Finland is finÃ©s. Be careful not to mix up nationalities and languages!

Just like nationalities, languages are never capitalized in Spanish.

Geographic vocabulary in Spanish

No, this section wonât talk about landforms in Spanish, although we do have a separate blog for that! This section will focus on the political side of geography, how humans organize ourselves: states, cities, countries, etc. Weâve even included the names of some international political organizations, such as the United Nations. Now youâre ready to sign up for a Model UN conference in Spanish!

Share your heritage wherever you go

Now that you know how to talk about places of origin, you can be a more confident representative of your home country as you travel through the Spanish speaking countries. Cultural exchange is one of the best parts of learning a new language, and thereâs plenty to learn when you meet someone from a different country or simply from a different town.
